bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Ford Foundation was chartered by Henry and Edsel Ford in 1936 "to receive and administer funds for scientific, educational and charitable purposes, all for the public welfare", and initially served the Ford family's charitable interests in the Detroit area. Following the deaths of Edsel Ford (1943) and Henry Ford (1947), the Foundation was propelled to the forefront of philanthropy as the largest American foundation in terms of both endowment and yearly expenditures, and with an international scope to its major program areas. During the Foundation's first twenty years its major programs were in international economic development, primary and higher education, educational and public broadcasting, behavioral sciences, civil liberties, urban development, fine arts and the humanities. The Ford Foundation also partnered with the Rockefeller Foundation in supporting agricultural development in South America, Africa, and Southeast Asia. Since the 1970s, the Foundation has also pioneered programs in women's rights, energy policy, micro-financing in under-developed countries, establishing human rights groups, and improving international HIV/AIDS education.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ford Foundation archive was deposited at the RAC in 2011. Ford Foundation records, correspondence, reports, program files, and officers' papers were transferred to and accessioned by the RAC beginning in 2011.
This material was transferred to the RAC in 2019 and was ingested by the RAC as Accession 2019:183.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Collection contains the office files Orlando Bagwell created when he worked as a Program Officer in the Media, Arts, and Culture Unit (MAC) of the Ford Foundation's Knowledge, Creativity, and Freedom Program (KCF). It consists of one series of subject files. These files document the activities Bagwell performed when carrying out his responsibilities for managing a grant portfolio focused on public media and media rights and access and for leading the Foundation's five-year Global Perspectives in a Digital Age: Transforming Public Service Media initiative. Some of the files in the series were inherited from Bagwell's MAC predecessors.

Common types of documents found throughout the collection include correspondence, memos, drafts, reports, proposals, concept papers, notes, film treatments, summaries, articles, abstracts, biographies, promotional materials, and publications. There is also one video tape.

Grantees discussed within the files received support for producing films about race and inequality in America, advancing the representation of Latino Americans in film and TV, strengthening and innovating public media, and assisting the Ford Foundation's Global Perspectives in a Digital Age: Transforming Public Service Media initiative.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Orlando Bagwell is a filmmaker and former Program Officer at the Ford Foundation. During his time at the Ford Foundation, he led the Foundation's five-year Global Perspectives in a Digital Age: Transforming Public Service Media initiative and then co-founded the Foundation's JustFilms initiative in 2010.
The first part of Bagwell's career was centered in Boston, Massachusetts. He produced for WGBH and founded ROJA Productions there.

Bagwell joined the Ford Foundation in 2004 as a Program Officer in the Media, Arts, and Culture Unit (MAC) of the Knowledge, Creativity, and Freedom Program (KCF). Within this position, Bagwell was responsible for managing a grant portfolio focused on public media and media rights and access. The JustFilms initiative that he helped establish in 2010 provides funding to documentary filmmakers focused on social justice storytelling and has supported films like How to Survive a Plague. Bagwell left the Ford Foundation in 2013.
In 2014, Bagwell became the director of the documentary program at the University of California Berkeley's Graduate School of Journalism. He continues to produce documentaries.

Bagwell earned a B.S. in film and then an M.A. in broadcast journalism from Boston University. Documentaries he has produced and or directed include Eyes on the Prize, Africans in America: America's Journey through Slavery, and episodes of American Experience such as Malcom X: Make It Plain and Citizen King.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains the subject files Orlando Bagwell created when he worked as a Program Officer in the Media, Arts, and Culture Unit (MAC) of the Ford Foundation's Knowledge, Creativity, and Freedom Program (KCF). Files regard the Foundation's support of grantees like California Newsreel, WGBH, and the National Hispanic Foundation for the Arts (NHFA). These organizations received funding for producing films on race and inequality in America, strengthening and innovating public media, and advancing the representation of Latino Americans in film and television. The files also provide evidence of some of the Foundation's self-directed projects regarding public service media and freedom of expression such as the Global Perspectives in a Digital Age: Transforming Public Service Media initiative and the Stone Soup (Ford Foundation Freedom of Expression Working Group) meetings. Some materials in the series were inherited from past MAC Program Officers like Jon Santos because the projects those records concerned were passed on to Bagwell.

Subject files regarding MAC's support of the California Newsreel film series Hidden Epidemic and RACE: The Power of an Illusion contain a significant amount of records such as film summaries and press articles related to the promotion of the series. There are also drafts of films treatments. Other type of materials found throughout the series include correspondence, memos, reports, proposals, concept papers, notes, abstracts, biographies, and publications.
